  • Try to contribute something new to the discussion, whether it is an extension, generalization or other idea related to the challenge.
  • Stay on topic — we're all here to learn more about math and science, not to hear about your favorite get-rich-quick scheme or current world events.

U may use the concept of fermat pt to solve this one..then it will be very easy...suppose three line segments AF,BF,CF of length x,y,z meet each other at120 degrees and now use cosine rule to find out the lengths of the triangle and see that each term on the rhs of the inequality is actually squares of the sides...then express xy+yz+zx as 43T\frac{4}{\sqrt{3}}T3​4​T where T is the area of the triangle....then use T=abc4RT=\frac{abc}{4R}T=4Rabc​ and see that the inequality reduces to 3R greater than or equal to (x+y+z) which is obvious since F is the fermat pt

  ⟹  b(1+3a)−10(3a+1)=507\implies b(1+3a) -10(3a + 1) = 507 ⟹b(1+3a)−10(3a+1)=507

  ⟹  (b−10)(3a+1)=507×1=13×39=3×169\implies (b-10)(3a+1) = 507 \times 1 = 13 \times 39 = 3 \times 169⟹(b−10)(3a+1)=507×1=13×39=3×169

Find all primes x,yx,yx,y such that xy−yx=xy2−19x^{y}-y^{x}=xy^{2}-19xy−yx=xy2−19.Enjoy solving this.

Souryajit Roy - 5 years, 7 months ago

Log in to reply

Using FLT, we have

xy≡x(mody)⇒x≡−19(mody)⇒x+19≡0(mody)x^y \equiv x \pmod{y} \Rightarrow x \equiv -19 \pmod {y} \Rightarrow x+19 \equiv 0 \pmod{y}xy≡x(mody)⇒x≡−19(mody)⇒x+19≡0(mody)

yx≡y(modx)⇒−y≡−19(modx)⇒19−y≡0(modx)y^x \equiv y \pmod{x} \Rightarrow -y \equiv -19 \pmod {x} \Rightarrow 19-y \equiv 0 \pmod{x}yx≡y(modx)⇒−y≡−19(modx)⇒19−y≡0(modx)

From here, it is clear that either x=2x=2x=2 or y=2y=2y=2. We now separate this into 2 cases:

Case 1: y=2y=2y=2

When y=2y=2y=2, we have 19−2=17≡0(modx)19 - 2 = 17 \equiv 0 \pmod{x}19−2=17≡0(modx), which implies x=17x=17x=17. The solution in this case is (17,2)(17, 2)(17,2). Checking, however, we find that this clearly doesn't work. So, there are no solutions in this case.

Case 2: x=2x=2x=2

When x=2x=2x=2, we have 19+2=21≡0(mody)19+2 = 21 \equiv 0 \pmod {y}19+2=21≡0(mody), which implies y=3y=3y=3 or y=7y=7y=7. Checking, we find both these solutions work. Thus, 2 solutions exist in this case: (2,3)(2, 3)(2,3) and (2,7)(2,7)(2,7).

Therefore, only 2 solutions exist: (2,3)(2, 3)(2,3) and (2,7)(2,7)(2,7).

1=ay+by2+cy3+dy4(1)1 = ay + by^2 + cy^3 + dy^4 \quad \quad (1)1=ay+by2+cy3+dy4(1)

−an+bn2+−cn+dn4=1\dfrac {-an+b}{n^2}+\dfrac{-cn+d}{n^4}=1n2−an+b​+n4−cn+d​=1

A Former Brilliant Member - 5 years, 7 months ago

Log in to reply

Let roots be p,q,r,s,tp,q,r,s,tp,q,r,s,t.

Sum of roots = -a & Product of roots taken two at a time = b.

Therefore Sum of squares of roots = a2−2ba^{2} - 2ba2−2b

If all roots are real, then by Titu's Lemma,

a2−2b≥a25a^{2} -2b \geq \frac{a^{2}}{5} a2−2b≥5a2​

  ⟹  2a2≥5b\implies 2a^{2} \geq 5b⟹2a2≥5b

Therefore the polynomial cannot have all roots real if 5b>2a2 5b > 2a^{2}5b>2a2.

Nihar Mahajan - 5 years, 7 months ago

Since the expression is symmetric, let's assume without loss of generality that x≥yx \ge yx≥y.

x2y−1+y2x−1≥y2y−1+y2x−1≥4+y2x−1  ⟹  x2y−1≥4\frac{x^{2}}{y-1}+\frac{y^{2}}{x-1} \ge \frac{y^{2}}{y-1}+\frac{y^{2}}{x-1} \ge 4+\frac{y^{2}}{x-1} \implies \frac{x^{2}}{y-1} \ge 4y−1x2​+x−1y2​≥y−1y2​+x−1y2​≥4+x−1y2​⟹y−1x2​≥4. Minimum value of x2y−1\frac{x^{2}}{y-1}y−1x2​ is 444 and it occurs if and only if x=y=2x=y=2x=y=2.

Therefore, x2y−1+y2x−1≥8\frac{x^{2}}{y-1}+\frac{y^{2}}{x-1} \ge 8y−1x2​+x−1y2​≥8.

The first two terms are zero, hence

Tn=(n+4j)−2n−8+3=(n+4)(n+3)2−2n−5T_n={n+4 \choose{j}}-2n-8+3=\frac{(n+4)(n+3)}{2}-2n-5Tn​=(jn+4​)−2n−8+3=2(n+4)(n+3)​−2n−5.

Hence, Tn=(n+1)(n+2)2T_n=\frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2}Tn​=2(n+1)(n+2)​ and Sn=12(n+3)(n+4)S_n=\frac{1}{2(n+3)(n+4)}Sn​=2(n+3)(n+4)1​.

Phew!!
